page.title: 09Buildings In Whitehills
page.content: {Whitehills} will interest students of architecture in that successive waves of development are clearly illustrated by different house sizes and styles. 1. The original fisher houses of { {Seatown}, end-on to the sea, once pantiled from the local tile-works. 2. Expansion outwards from the shore to {New Road (Ogilvie St.)} and {New {St. (Grant St.)} 3. Post-1918 expansion along {Knock {St.} and {Grant St.}Larger houses of distinctly different type. 4. Late 1920s-30s. Substantial houses built by skipper/owners fish buyers ship chandlers and the like along { {Seafield St. and Reidhaven St.} 5. Successive phases of Council Building with slum clearance from{Low {Shore} landwards, with a new school in 1977 and some private bungalows in {Knock St. and Reidhaven St.
